summary: This is a civil complaint filed by the Government of the United States Virgin Islands (GVI) against the Estate of Jeffrey E. Epstein and several corporate entities (The 1953 Trust, Plan D, LLC, Great St. Jim, LLC, Nautilus, Inc., Hyperion Air, LLC, Poplar, Inc.). The complaint alleges these entities formed an 'Epstein Enterprise' that facilitated and concealed sex trafficking, sexual abuse, and forced labor of young women and underage girls on Epstein's private islands, Little St. James and Great St. James. It seeks damages and outlines the corporate structure used to shield assets and enable criminal activity. This document is a section of a civil complaint filed by the Government of the Virgin Islands (GVI) against the Estate of Jeffrey E. Epstein. It details allegations that the 'Epstein Enterprise' engaged in human trafficking, forced labor, and sexual servitude in the US Virgin Islands, violated environmental and construction laws, and used a network of shell companies to conceal assets and criminal activity. The complaint seeks civil penalties, damages, and forfeiture of properties. This document is a section of a civil complaint filed by the Government of the Virgin Islands (GVI) against the Estate of Jeffrey E. Epstein and other unnamed Defendants. It details multiple counts under the Criminally Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act (CICO), alleging the operation of a criminal enterprise for human trafficking, sexual servitude, child abuse, rape, and prostitution involving minors and young women at Epstein's properties, particularly Little St. James in the U.S. Virgin Islands. This is the final section of a civil complaint filed by the Government of the United States Virgin Islands (GVI) against the Estate of Jeffrey Epstein and other defendants. It details multiple counts under the Criminally Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act (CICO), including sex offender registry violations, fraudulent conveyance, and civil conspiracy. The document seeks extensive relief, including forfeiture of property, dissolution of the Epstein Enterprise, and punitive damages.

connections.description: Indyke served as an executor of Epstein's estate and as an officer (secretary) in Epstein's corporate entities (Nautilus, Inc., Poplar, Inc.).
Kahn served as an executor of Epstein's estate and as an officer (treasurer) in Epstein's corporate entity Nautilus, Inc.
Visoski was Epstein's pilot and was listed as the manager/member of corporate entities (Plan D, LLC, Hyperion Air, LLC) that owned aircraft used by Epstein.
The executors of Epstein's estate are trustees of The 1953 Trust and officers in Epstein entities, and are alleged to be continuing efforts to conceal assets and criminal activity.
The complaint alleges that all Defendants conspired with Epstein to fulfill the primary criminal purposes of the Epstein Enterprise, including human trafficking, forced labor, and sexual servitude.

events.title: Acquisition of Little St. James
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein acquired the private island of Little St. James in the Virgin Islands, which the complaint alleges became a hideaway for trafficking and sexual abuse.

events.title: Epstein Registers as Sex Offender in VI
events.description: Epstein registered as a Tier 1 sex offender in the Virgin Islands following his Florida conviction, requiring annual registration and travel notifications.

events.title: Acquisition of Great St. James
events.description: Epstein, through Great St. Jim, LLC, purchased the neighboring island of Great St. James, allegedly to further shield criminal activities on Little St. James.

events.title: Death of Jeffrey Epstein
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was found dead in custody in New York while facing sex crime charges.

events.title: Estate Probate Filed
events.description: Executors Darren K. Indyke and Richard Kahn filed a Petition for Probate and Letters Testamentary for Epstein's estate in the Virgin Islands Superior Court.

events.title: Epstein Refuses Full Sex Offender Verification
events.description: During a sex offender registration verification, Epstein refused to allow Virgin Islands investigators and U.S. Marshals to enter Little St. James beyond the dock, claiming it was his 'front door.' He instead arranged to meet at his office on St. Thomas.

events.title: Epstein Misleads on Travel Plans
events.description: The Virgin Islands was notified Epstein would travel to France for 10 days on a private plane. His notification form did not disclose travel to Vienna and Monaco, which law enforcement later discovered.

events.title: Estate Files Motion for Claims Resolution Program
events.description: Epstein's Estate filed an Expedited Motion to establish a voluntary claims resolution program for sexual abuse claims, which included confidentiality requirements and required claimants to sacrifice other claims.

events.title: Epstein Amends Trust and Will Before Death
events.description: Two days before his death, Epstein amended The 1953 Trust and his Last Will and Testament, allegedly as part of an ongoing effort to conceal and shield his assets from potential recovery by claimants.

events.title: Epstein's Unreported Foreign Travel
events.description: Epstein, a registered sex offender, traveled to Vienna and Monaco on at least two occasions without disclosing the travel to the Virgin Islands sex offender registry as required by law.

events.title: Fraudulent Asset Transfer to The 1953 Trust
events.description: Days before his death, Epstein allegedly transferred significant assets, including assets held by other defendants, into The 1953 Trust in an effort to defeat creditor claims and avoid probate court oversight.

events.title: Filing of GVI Civil Complaint
events.description: The Government of the U.S. Virgin Islands files this extensive civil complaint against Epstein's estate and other defendants, alleging 22 counts related to a criminal enterprise.

keyFacts: The Government of the Virgin Islands alleges that Jeffrey Epstein and a network of corporate entities (the 'Epstein Enterprise') engaged in a pattern of sex trafficking, sexual abuse, and forced labor of young women and underage girls on his private islands, Little St. James and Great St. James.

Epstein's estate, valued at over $577 million in Virgin Islands assets alone, is being sued for damages related to these alleged crimes, along with specific corporate entities that held his properties and aircraft.

The complaint details how Epstein used a complex web of Virgin Islands corporations (Nautilus, Inc., Great St. Jim, LLC, Poplar, Inc., Plan D, LLC, Hyperion Air, LLC) to hold assets, facilitate travel for victims, and conceal his criminal activity.

Specific allegations include victims as young as 12-17 years old being transported to the islands, held captive, forced to perform sexual acts, and attempting to escape by swimming from Little St. James.

Epstein purchased Great St. James in 2016, after becoming a registered sex offender, allegedly to create a buffer zone to prevent detection of activities on Little St. James and to hinder victims from escaping or seeking help.
The 'Epstein Enterprise' is accused of using the seclusion of Little St. James and Great St. James to traffic, harbor, and sexually abuse young women and children, and to conceal these crimes.

The Enterprise allegedly created a complex network of shell companies (e.g., Financial Informatics, Inc., Financial Trust Company, Inc.) in the Virgin Islands, some holding hundreds of millions in assets, to conceal its identity, fund its activities, and shield assets.

Epstein and his enterprise actively obstructed law enforcement and regulatory inspections, including sex offender verification visits and environmental inspections, by claiming constitutional privacy over entire islands.

The complaint alleges that even after Epstein's death, the Enterprise continued to exist and conspire to prevent detection and accountability, with the Estate proposing a claims program that would impose confidentiality and limit liability.
The illegal construction activity on the islands has caused, and will cause, significant environmental damage and remediation expenses for the Virgin Islands.

The complaint alleges the existence of the 'Epstein Enterprise,' an illicit organization engaged in human trafficking, forced labor, and sexual servitude of girls and young women in the U.S. Virgin Islands.
It claims underage girls and young women were given scholarships, money, or gifts in exchange for engaging in sexual acts with Jeffrey Epstein and other unnamed Defendants.
The property at Little St. James is specifically identified as being used for the purpose of prostitution, lewdness, or assignation, with knowledge that some individuals involved were minors.

The legal action is brought under the Virgin Islands' Criminally Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act (CICO), alleging a pattern of criminal activity including child abuse, aggravated rape, and unlawful sexual contact.

The complaint repeatedly states that Defendants (other than Epstein's estate) conspired with Epstein and each other to fulfill the criminal purposes of the enterprise and benefited financially or otherwise from their participation.
The complaint alleges Epstein violated the Virgin Islands sex offender registry laws by failing to report his travel to Vienna and Monaco.
Epstein is accused of fraudulently conveying assets into 'The 1953 Trust' days before his death to avoid creditors and probate court jurisdiction.
The Government seeks forfeiture of Epstein's Virgin Islands properties, including Little St. James and Greater St. James Islands, as assets used to facilitate the criminal enterprise.
The document outlines a civil conspiracy claim, alleging all defendants acted in concert to conceal the sexual abuse of minors.
The Government gives formal notice of its intent to seek punitive damages against the defendants.
